 As seen on:
PLAY

RISC OS is an open source computer operating system (OS) with a graphical user interface (GUI) that was first released in 1987 by Acorn Computers and designed to run on ARM RISC processors.
ARM processors are uniquely outstanding in their power efficiency, which is why they can be found in over 90% of all mobile phones in the world today. These include Apple (iPhone), Samsung, Huawei, OPPO and many other cell phone manufacturers.
RISC OS is an alternative to operating systems such as MS Windows, Linux or macOS. RISC OS provides a faster user experience, a flexible development environment, and energy-saving processor technology.
We’ve designed a fully integrated system that runs RISC OS on a powerful hardware device that we call Cloverleaf. 
RISC OS is the first and original OS that ran on ARM RISC CPUs. It is a 32-bit OS with cooperative multitasking. It was designed with a graphical user interface with many outstanding features like contextual menus and a three-button mouse.
From the beginning, it has included a vector-graphics program. One key feature is its modular design which offer programmers easy access to all areas of the OS. RISC OS also includes BBC BASIC as its main programming language.
We’re building the Cloverleaf RISC OS for you. With the user in mind, RISC OS is an OS for users who want a more efficient and robust OS. Cloverleaf RISC OS comes with a large list of free programs that cover most areas (see under section "Free Software" below for detailed information). 
RISC OS is the right OS for explorers and tinkerers as it doesn't restrict your access to the hardware and you can create any software you like. You can control external hardware using the 40-pin GPIO connector — the same as used in the Raspberry Pi™ and Arduino™. For programming beginners there is the built-in BBC BASIC which is the perfect tool to learn programming. BBC BASIC also opens up the doors directly to the heart of the hardware, the widely-used ARM CPU, as one awesome feature of BBC BASIC is the possibility to include ARM assembler code directly in your BASIC programs.
Cloverleaf RISC OS is your choice to reduce your carbon footprint. At Cloverleaf, we are firm believers that we must find sustainable solutions to power our computers to fight global warming.
Thanks to RISC OS and ARM CPUs, Cloverleaf is making it possible to build low-power systems available for everyone. We have the technology to deliver systems that run on 5 - 15 W of power rather than 80 - 300 W on your current desktop computer. At this low-power consumption a RISC OS computer can be easily powered by a small solar panel.
RISC OS provides a feature that every computer user needs: speed. 
RISC OS was originally written for ARM chips with a clock rate of only 8 MHz! The RockChip RK3399 SoC used for our Cloverleaf hardware runs now at 1.8 GHz. That is 225 times faster than the original CPU. The handling speed of RISC OS has improved nearly 100 times in the last 30 years. 
Another factor of the fast and responsive user experience is the cooperative multitasking of RISC OS. This ensures that the application you are currently using at any moment gets the processing time it needs to finish its current task. Only then does the CPU move on to the next task.
RISC OS programs use minimum space in your computer’s memory because the original OS was designed for a computer with half a megabyte of RAM rather than several gigabytes like most of the operating systems on the market today. RISC OS can run happily in 256 MB and still have 200 MB free for applications. Our current Cloverleaf hardware offers 4GB of RAM so there is plenty of free space for data and programs.
With no need for virtual memory, RISC OS runs your programs faster than on other operating systems, especially when overloaded.
Many computer users may find themselves frustrated with operating systems such as MS Windows and macOS and with good reason. Forced computer upgrades or OS upgrades usually occur every three to five years.
Each time a user installs new hardware in their computer, these monopolist companies make gargantuan profits by taking advantage of the ‘need’ to upgrade.
How often have you had to buy new hardware such as printers, scanners, graphics cards, and sound cards because new versions of the OS do not have drivers? How much has your company had to pay for upgrading third-party software because of incompatibilities with new operating systems?
We don’t believe that this is right. That’s why Cloverleaf will build a smart, user-friendly OS that doesn’t force you to upgrade your computer hardware every four years or upgrade your software to newer versions.
Because this technology was built right in the first place, you can be confident that RISC OS will perform as powerfully ten years from now as the day you take it out of the box.
PLAY

The RISC OS operating system is right choice for retro gaming lovers and computer hobbyists. RISC OS offers a number of emulators for well known retro computers as the Commodore C64, Sinclair ZX Spectrum, the Acorn Micro and the Acorn Archimedes. In addition to games in these emulators, a plethora of games have been ported to RISC OS from Linux and other platforms, including commercial titles like Elite, Duke Nukem, Lemmings,  and Heroes of Might and Magic 2. RISC OS also develops and releases new games frequently.
Also available on RISC OS is the well-known ScummVM, which allows you to perform numerous adventures and RPGs. ScummVM supports an extensive library of over 250 adventure games - including many classics from legendary studios such as LucasArts, Sierra On-Line, and Revolution Software. ResidualVM is also available to play 3D adventure games on RISC OS, including Grim Fandango, Escape from Monkey Island, and Myst III: Exile.
Because RISC OS is such a compact and resource-efficient OS, it will happily run in a few megabytes of RAM rather than gigabytes—making it the perfect tool for any computer hobbyist. RISC OS, unlike most operating systems, is barebones out of the box. RISC OS is great for 2D vector graphics, DTP, and programming whatever you have in mind in BBC BASIC/ARM assembler, C/C++, Python, RiscLua and others.
PLAY

The Raspberry Pi is an affordable single-board computer that is very versatile. It can be used for a variety of tasks, including electronic projects, games, media servers, secure Internet proxy servers, robotics, spreadsheets, word-processing, and more. But Linux pushes this lightweight hardware to its limits.
In contrast, RISC OS was designed for much less powerful ARM CPUs and
    smaller memory sizes, and is therefore a perfect match for any
    Raspberry Pi.
Because the lightweight RISC OS was designed to run on ARM processors and doesn’t need gigabytes of memory to perform, Cloverleaf’s RISC OS distribution is perfect for your Raspberry Pi Zero, 2, 3, and 4.
RISC OS is for explorers who want to have new experiences and seek exciting computer solutions. Those who want to do more with their OS at faster speeds will love RISC OS’s intuitive straight-forward technology.
Plain and simple, many computer users are fed up with monopolists, and are looking for alternative solutions that better meet their needs. Instead of dealing with constant, expensive updates and constricting hardware and software, RISC OS explorers can experience a completely new OS world while being environmentally conscious.
Cloverleaf’s system is the ultimate tool for tinkerers, makers, and programming ninjas as well as for computer beginners.
RISC OS was introduced by Acorn Computers in 1987, and was bundled with every ARM-based computer manufactured by the company. Acorn Computers created the fast, ultra-efficient ARM CPU. For this revolutionary RISC CPU, the operating system RISC OS was created. It was popularized by Acorn's Archimedes computer; Acorn machines were used in almost all UK schools and universities during the 1980s and 1990s.
The OS has undergone several updates since its inception, with the latest version being RISC OS 5.28. As of October 2018, RISC OS was made fully open source, and it is now licensed under the Apache License 2.0.
Some of the greatest features of Cloverleaf’s OS are the included software and programming tools that are available for free.
In the box with every Cloverleaf computer, users can expect the revolutionary ARM technology, teamed with its original, radical OS, RISC OS. 
In our Cloverleaf RISC OS distribution, we include a collection of the best free programs and tools available, so that you have a wide range of choices for your daily tasks.
Some of the available programs include:
    A powerful Word Processing & DTP System (Impression Style)
    Pipedream as spreadsheet, database, and word processor
    Fireworkz (spreadsheet and word processor)
    ChatCube (Instant messenger with integrated client for Telegram)
    GCC as a GNU Compiler Collection for C++
    BBC BASIC which allows users to easily write directly in ARM assembler without needing a compiler 
    Python 2 & 3, the most popular language for machine learning and artificial intelligence
    RiscLua, a powerful, efficient, lightweight, embeddable scripting language
    Games collection (RISC OS games, Acorn Archimedes, ZX Spectrum, Acorn BBC Micro, Commodore C64, & ScummVM)
    MessergerPro (Email & News client)
    OpenVector (Vector graphics program)
    Merlin (3D editor and raytracing)

We are building RISC OS for ultimate convenience. Now, it will be easier than ever to access our outstanding collection of games and emulators for:
Sinclair ZX Spectrum
Acorn BBC Micro
Acorn Archimedes
MSDOS
Comodore C64
  You’ll have access to a wide range of retro games on these platforms, as they will be included in our collections. Not to mention that you can access even more games and programs through PlingStore and PackMan. 
RISC OS Cloverleaf is a crowdfunding campaign to upgrade and revive the unique  computer operating system RISC OS. With Cloverleaf, we’re aiming to build a new brand for the RISC OS operating system that gives users an exciting and user-friendly alternative to monopolists like Microsoft, Apple, and Google.
We believe that users need more choices for computer operating systems. The current market for powering our computers is currently insufficient; we must give consumers the option to no longer be dependent on only three companies.
This project is about developing RISC OS. When you receive your first version of RISC OS, it won’t be at its final development stage. Improvements will come out on a monthly basis, with new programs and upgrades available over time.
Cloverleaf aims to build community. That’s why we’ll always be available and happy to receive your feedback, so we can ensure that your experience and desires using RISC OS will be met!
Our project targets include adding support for WIFI, USB 3, Bluetooth, NMVe, multi-threading, GPU and multi-language support for all major languages.
 Cloverleaf has a wide variety of Funding Offers which gives users simple pricing on great products. With any purchase, 100€ will be put towards the development of RISC OS as the best alternative computer OS. The available options include: 

Cloverleaf RISC OS Supporter (99€/~$110/~£90): Support the development of RISC OS, reduction of the tech industry’s carbon dioxide footprint, and creative diversity in the IT world with this offer. This also includes a software download.
Cloverleaf Kitten Desktop PC (299€/~$330/~£275): 
This package includes a starter RISC OS system with a quadcore ARM processor, 4 GB DDR4, and a 128GB SDRAM card. This mini desktop computer is available with different color combinations (wood/green, black/red, black/blue or pink/transparent). This includes the computer case with external GPIO and power supply.
Cloverleaf Puma 16/256 SD Desktop PC (399€/~$439/~£359): The same as the Puma computer below but with a with 16 GB EMMC and a 256 GB SD card.
Cloverleaf Puma 64/256 NVMe Desktop PC (599€/~$660/~£550): Don’t miss the chance to get your hands on this high-end RISC OS system based on Rockchip RK3399, an hexacore ARM processor, 4 GB DDRam 4, 64 GB EMMC and a 256 GB NVMe drive. This also features and includes a computer case with external GPIO, and a power supply.
Cloverleaf Notebook 14” Laptop (599€/~$660/~£550): The purchase of this laptop provides users with a High-End RISC OS system based on Rockchip RK3399, an hexacore ARM processor, 4 GB DDRam 4, a 128 GB NVMe drive, a computer case, wireless keyboard, wireless mouse, and power supply.
Cloverleaf 24” All-In-One PC (899€/~$990/~£815): The Cloverleaf All-In-One PC with a 23.8" display is the most powerful and capable computer and available in white or black including wireless keyboard and mouse. Also based on the Rockchip RK3399, this purchase includes an hexacore ARM processor, 4 GB DDRam 4, 128 GB EMMC and a 256 GB SD card. This offer includes also a wireless keyboard and mouse.
You are a wealthy individual or are a company or an organization that wants to see RISC OS grow as fast as possible. Then you can opt for our supreme supporter offer. You can choose which open source project you like us to port to RISC OS. This will enable us to work for 4 month on each software package. The port might not be fully completed during that time but should have major features.
Some of the software packages might need at least two or three fundings (2/3) to be fully ported. The porting will also depend on the current technical limitations of RISC OS. For example RISC OS currently has no access to the ARM Mali GPU. So OpenGL can currently only be implemented with software rendering. 
Here a list of possible open source software that can be ported to RISC OS:

lazarus-ide.org (former Borland Delphi IDE)(2) This includes the freepascal.org.
kicad-pcb.org (2) (PCB layout)
lmms.io (digital audio worksation)
audacityteam.org (digital audio worksation)
OpenGL (3D library) (2)
godotengine.org (2D/3D Games engine) (3)
libreoffice.org (Office package)(3)
openoffice.org  (Office package)(3)
rust-lang.org (programming language)(2)
gnumeric.org (spreadsheet)(1)
The main figures behind this project are Stefan Fröhling (former Evolution Computer GmbH, Germany) and Andrew Rawnsley (R-Comp Interactive, United Kingdom). Both have a long history related to RISC OS. Stefan was active in RISC OS products 20 to 25 years ago and came back to RISC OS two years ago and is the initiator of the Cloverleaf RISC OS project. 
Stefan found a competent partner in Andrew who was active in RISC OS business during the last 25 Years, and has many years of experience delivering five generations of RISC OS computer systems.  Andrew is also co-owner of the RISC OS intellectual property (IP) and is actively involved in all areas of its development and deployment.
There are many helpers behind the scenes that want to support RISC OS for various reasons. Most help us with advice or work in their free time to support the development of RISC OS. Some released their RISC OS software for free to the RISC OS community. Some of them we want to mention here: Raik Fischer, Jeffrey Lee, Jason Tribbeck, Andy Marks, Micheal Grundlitz, David Higton, Tom Williamson, Andrew Conroy, Gavin Smith, David Feugey, Paolo Fabio Zaino, Peter Howkins, Nemo, Richard Hallas and many more. (Sorry if we forgot someone in the list)
  RISC OS ist ein Open-Source-Computer-Betriebssystem mit einer grafischen Benutzerinferenz (GUI), das erstmals 1989 von Acorn Computers veröffentlicht wurde, um auf ARM RISC-Prozessoren ausgeführt zu werden.
ARM-Prozessoren zeichnen sich durch eine herausragende Energieeffizienz aus, weshalb sie derzeit in über 90% aller Mobiltelefone der Welt zu finden sind. Dazu gehören Apple (iPhone), Samsung, Huawei, OPPO und viele andere Handyhersteller.
RISC OS ist eine Alternative zu Betriebssystemen wie MS Windows und MacOS, die eine schnellere Benutzererfahrung, eine flexible Entwicklungsumgebung und energiesparende Prozessortechnologie bietet.
Wir haben ein vollständig integriertes System entwickelt, auf dem RISC OS auf einem leistungsstarken Hardwaregerät ausgeführt wird, das wir Cloverleaf nennen.
RISC OS ist das erste und ursprüngliche Betriebssystem, das auf ARM RISC-CPUs ausgeführt wurde. RISC bedeuted nicht Risiko, sondern Reduzierter-Befehlssatz-Chip. RISC OS ist ein kooperatives Multitasking-32-Bit-Betriebssystem. Es wurde mit einer grafischen Benutzeroberfläche mit vielen herausragenden Funktionen wie Kontextmenüs und einer Maus mit drei Tasten entworfen. Es enthielt von Anfang an ein Vektorgrafikprogramm. Ein wesentliches Merkmal ist der modulare Aufbau, der Programmierern einen einfachen Zugriff auf alle Bereiche des Betriebssystems bietet. RISC OS enthält auch BBC BASIC als Hauptprogrammiersprache.
OS ist ein Betriebssystem für Anwender, die ein effizienteres und robusteres Betriebssystem wünschen. Das Cloverleaf RISC OS kommt mit einer großen Liste kostenloser Programme, die die meisten Anwendungen abdecken (Detailierte Information finden sie weiter unten bei "Gratis-Software"). RISC OS ist das richtige Betriebssystem für Entdecker und Bastler, da es Ihren Zugriff auf die Hardware nicht einschränkt und Sie jede gewünschte Software erstellen können. Sie können über das 40-PIN-GPIO wie Raspberry oder Arduino auf externe Geräte zugreifen. Für Programmieranfänger gibt es das eingebaute BBC BASIC, das das perfekte Werkzeug zum Erlernen des Programmierens ist. Dies macht es perfekt für Kinder, ihre ersten Schritte in die Computerwelt zu machen. BBC BASIC öffnet aber auch die Türen direkt zum Herzen der Hardware. Die weit verbreitete ARM-CPU als eine großartige Funktion von BBC BASIC bietet die Möglichkeit, ARM-Assembler-Code direkt in Ihre BASIC-Programme aufzunehmen. Mit Cloverleaf RISC OS sind die Möglichkeiten endlos. Benutzer haben die Möglichkeit, das Betriebssystem selbst zu ändern, da es Open Source ist und für jede Aufgabe übernommen werden kann.
Cloverleaf RISC OS ist Ihre erste Wahl, um Ihren CO2-Fußabdruck zu reduzieren. Wir bei Cloverleaf sind fest davon überzeugt, dass wir nachhaltige Lösungen für die Stromversorgung unserer Computer finden müssen, um der globalen Erderwärmung entgegenzuwirken. Dank RISC OS- und ARM-CPUs ermöglicht Cloverleaf den Aufbau von Systemen mit sehr geringerem Stromverbrauch, die für alle verfügbar sind. Wir verfügen über die Technologie, um Systeme mit einer Verbrauch von 5 W bis 15 W, gegenüber 80 W bis 300 W auf Ihrem aktuellen Desktop-Computer, bereitzustellen. Bei diesem geringen Stromverbrauch kann ein RISC OS-Computer problemlos mit einem kleinen Solarpanel betrieben werden.
RISC OS bietet eine Funktion, die jeder Computerbenutzer benötigt: Geschwindigkeit. RISC OS wurde ursprünglich für RISC-CPUs mit nur 8 MHz (!) Taktrate geschrieben. Der aktuelle RockChip RK3399 SoC, der für unsere Cloverleaf-Hardware verwendet wird, läuft jetzt mit 1,8 GHz. Das ist 225-mal schneller als die ursprünglichen CPUs. Da die GUI bei der Erstellung von RISC OS bereits sehr weit fortgeschritten war, hat sich bis jetzt nicht viel geändert und es wird auch nicht viel mehr Rechenleistung benötigt. Daher hat sich die Handhabungsgeschwindigkeit von RISC OS in den letzten 30 Jahren fast 100-mal beschleunigt. Ein weiterer Faktor für die schnelle Benutzererfahrung ist das kooperative Multitasking von RISC OS. Dadurch wird sichergestellt, dass die aktuelle Anwendung, die Sie derzeit verwenden, die Verarbeitungszeit erhält, die zum Beenden der aktuellen Aufgabe erforderlich ist. Erst dann übergibt es die CPU für die nächste Aufgabe. RISC-Betriebssystemprogramme belegen einen minimalen Speicherplatz im Arbeitsspeicher Ihres Computers, da der Ursprung des Betriebssystems auf 1 MB (!) RAM und nicht auf mehreren GByte beruhte, wie bei den meisten derzeit auf dem Markt befindlichen Betriebssystemen. RISC OS kann problemlos mit 256 MB RAM ausgeführt werden und verfügt immer noch über 200 MB freien Speicher für Anwendungen. Unsere aktuelle Cloverleaf-Hardware bietet 4 GB RAM, sodass genügend freier Speicherplatz für Daten und Programme vorhanden ist. Da kein virtueller Speicher verwendet wird, führt RISC OS Ihre Programme schneller aus als auf anderen überlasteten Betriebssystemen.
Viele Computerbenutzer sind möglicherweise aus gutem Grund mit Betriebssystemen, wie MS Windows und MacOS frustriert. Erzwungene Computer- oder Betriebssystem-Upgrades werden normalerweise alle drei bis fünf Jahre durchgeführt. Jedes Mal, wenn ein Benutzer neue Hardware auf seinem Computer installiert, erzielen diese monopolistischen Unternehmen enorme Gewinne, indem sie die Notwendigkeit eines Upgrades nutzen. Wie oft mussten Sie neue Hardware wie Drucker, Scanner, Grafikkarten und Soundkarten kaufen, da es für die neue Version des Betriebssystems keinen Treiber für Ihre alte Hardware gibt? Wie viel Servicekosten musste Ihr Unternehmen für das Upgrade von Software von Drittanbietern aufgrund von Inkompatibilitäten mit dem neuen Betriebssystem bezahlen? Wir glauben nicht, dass dies richtig ist. Aus diesem Grund wird Cloverleaf ein intelligentes, benutzerfreundliches Computer-Betriebssystem erstellen, das Sie nicht zwingt, Ihre Computerhardware alle vier Jahre zu aktualisieren oder Ihre Software auf neuere Versionen zu aktualisieren. Da diese Technologie von Anfang an entwickelt wurde, können Sie sicher sein, dass RISC OS in zehn Jahren genauso leistungsfähig sein wird wie an dem Tag, an dem Sie es aus der Verpackung nehmen.
Das Betriebssystem RISC OS ist auch die richtige Wahl für Retro-Gaming-Liebhaber und Computer-Hobbyisten. RISC OS bietet eine Reihe von Emulatoren für bekannte Retro-Computer, wie Commodore C64, Sinclair ZX Spectrum, Acorn Micro und Acorn Archimedes. Neben original Retro-Titeln wurde eine Vielzahl von Spielen von Linux und anderen Plattformen auf RISC OS portiert, darunter kommerzielle Titel, wie "Elite", "Duke Nukem", "Lemmings", "Heroes of Might" und "Magic 2". RISC OS Benutzer entwickelt und veröffentlicht auch häufig neue Spiele. Ebenfalls auf RISC OS verfügbar ist das bekannte ScummVM, welches Ihnen ermöglicht, zahlreiche Adventures und RPGs auszuführen. ScummVM unterstützt eine umfangreiche Bibliothek von über 250 Adventure-Spielen - darunter viele Klassiker legendärer Studios wie LucasArts, Sierra On-Line, Revolution Software. ResidualVM ist auch verfügbar, um 3D Abenteuerspiele auf RISC OS zu spielen, dazu gehören Grim Fandango, Escape von Monkey Island und Myst III: Exile.
Der Raspberry Pi ist ein erschwinglicher Mini-Computer, der sehr vielseitig ist. Es kann für eine Vielzahl von Aufgaben verwendet werden, darunter elektronische Projekte, Spiele, Medienserver, sichere Internet-Proxyserver, Robotik, Tabellenkalkulationen, Textverarbeitung und mehr. Aber Linux-Distributionen bringen die günstige Hardware schnell an ihre Grenzen. Im Gegensatz dazu wurde RISC OS für viel weniger leistungsstarke ARM-CPUs und kleinere Speichergrößen entwickelt und passt daher perfekt zu jedem Raspberry Pi. Da das ressourcenschonende RISC-Betriebssystem ausschließlich für die effizienten ARM-Prozessor konzipiert wurde und keine Gigabyte Speicher benötigt, ist das Cloverleaf RISC-Betriebssystem perfekt für Ihren Raspberry Pi Zero, 2, 3 und 4.
RISC OS ist für Entdecker gedacht, die neue Erfahrungen machen und nach aufregenden Computerlösungen suchen. Wer schneller mit seinem Betriebssystem mehr anfangen möchte, wird die intuitive, unkomplizierte Technologie von RISC OS lieben. Schlicht und einfach, viele Computerbenutzer haben die Nase voll von Monopolisten und suchen nach alternativen Lösungen, die ihren Anforderungen besser entsprechen. Anstatt sich mit ständigen, teuren Updates und eingeschränkter Hardware und Software zu befassen, können RISC OS-Entdecker, dass sie mehr Computer eine neues, schnelles Betriebssystem erforschen und dabei noch umweltbewusst handeln. Das Cloverleaf-System ist das ultimative Werkzeug für Bastler, Hersteller und Programmier-Ninjas sowie für Computeranfänger.
Eine der größten Vorteile des Cloverleaf RISC OS-Betriebssystems ist die beiliegende Software und Programmsprachen, die kostenlos zur Verfügung steht.
Einige der verfügbaren Programme umfassen:
Ein leistungsstarkes Textverarbeitungs- und DTP-System (Impression Style)
Pipedream als Tabellenkalkulation, Datenbank und Textverarbeitung
Fireworkz (Tabellenkalkulation und Textverarbeitung)
ChatCube (Instant Messenger mit integriertem Client für Telegramm)
GCC als GNU Compiler Collection für C ++
BBC BASIC, mit dem Benutzer problemlos direkt in ARM Assembler schreiben können, ohne einen Compiler zu benötigen
Python 2 & 3, die beliebteste Sprache für maschinelles Lernen und künstliche Intelligenz
RiscLua, eine leistungsstarke, effiziente, leichte und einbettbare Skriptsprache      
MessergerPro (Email & News Client)
Jetzt ist es einfacher als je zuvor, auf unsere herausragende Sammlung von Spielen und Emulatoren zuzugreifen, um:
Sinclair ZX Spectrum
Commodore C64
Acorn BBC Micro
Acorn Archimedes
MSDOS
Auf diesen Plattformen haben Sie Zugriff auf eine Vielzahl von Retro-Spielen, die in unsere Sammlungen aufgenommen werden. Ganz zu schweigen davon, dass Sie über PlingStore und PackMan auf noch mehr Spiele und Programme zugreifen können. Bist du ein Programmierer? Interessieren Sie sich für das Programmieren? Wir haben die Tools, Compiler und Programme für alle Ihre Anforderungen an Creative Computing.
RISC OS Cloverleaf ist eine Crowdfunding-Kampagne zur Aktualisierung und Wiederbelebung des einzigartigen und dynamischen Computerbetriebssystems RISC OS. Mit Cloverleaf wollen wir eine neuen Markt für das Betriebssystem RISC OS aufbauen, die Benutzern eine aufregende und benutzerfreundliche Alternative zu Monopolisten wie Microsoft, Apple und Google bietet.
In diesem Projekt geht es um die Entwicklung von RISC OS. Wenn Sie Ihre erste Version von RISC OS erhalten, befindet es sich noch nicht am Endpunkt der Entwicklung.
Während Sie bereits eine Menge großartiger Tools zur Verfügung haben, ist dies erst der Beginn der Entwicklung von RISC OS. Die Verbesserungen werden monatlich veröffentlicht, wobei im Laufe der Zeit neue Programme und Upgrades verfügbar sind.

Um RISC OS schneller weiterzuentwickeln, benötigen wir Ihre Hilfe. Mit Ihrer Unterstützung können wir das bereits herausragende Betriebssystem RISC OS nutzen und es noch benutzerfreundlicher weiter verbessern und an heutige Anforderungen anpassen. 
Unsere Projektziele umfassen Unterstützung von WIFI, USB 3, NMVe, Multithreading, GPU und mehrsprachige Unterstützung für alle wichtigen Sprachen.
Sie sind eine wohlhabende Person oder ein Unternehmen oder eine Organisation, die möchte, dass RISC OS so schnell wie möglich wächst. Dann können Sie sich für unser höchstes Unterstützerangebot entscheiden. Sie können auswählen, welches Open Source-Projekt wir auf RISC OS portieren sollen. Auf diese Weise können wir 4 Monate lang an jedem Softwarepaket arbeiten. Der Port ist in dieser Zeit möglicherweise nicht vollständig fertiggestellt, sollte jedoch über wichtige Funktionen verfügen. Einige der Softwarepakete benötigen möglicherweise mindestens zwei oder drei Mittel (2/3), um vollständig portiert zu werden. Die Portierung hängt auch von den aktuellen technischen Einschränkungen von RISC OS ab. Beispielsweise hat RISC OS derzeit keinen Zugriff auf die ARM Mali-GPU. Daher kann OpenGL derzeit nur mit Software-Rendering implementiert werden. 
Die Beispielliste möglicher Open Source-Software, die auf RISC OS portiert werden können, bitte im englischen Text ansehen.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As we are using existing hardware we will not have any risk of technological matter. The only risk is that we cannot keep the planned timeline to adopt the RISC OS hardware access layer (HAL) to the hardware and develope the corresponding drivers in time as anticipated. For example the display output uses different systems on the desktop PC, the laptop or the All-in-one PC. So when it works on the desktop PC then not automatically the laptop or the All-in-one PC will work at the same time.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Long-lasting design
RISC OS computers are designed to be used for centuries as the operating system doesn't force you to update your hardware every 3 to 5 years. The Acorn RiscPC which was delivered 30 years ago is still in use by many RISC OS users. We want to make available this unique operating around the world so they don't need to throw away their hardware every 5 years.
Reusability and recyclability
We will use packaging based on paper that is fully recyclable.
Sustainable Distribution

updates.update_userinfo: Full HTML5 and Javascript capable browser available now for RISC OS
updates.update_content:
Good news for the RISC OS world that finally a full blown RISC OS browser "Iris" is available now.
You can get it from the !Store on your RISC OS system.
This is a big step for RISC OS to make it competitive to other operating systems.
It runs only on real RISC OS hardware ARMv7 and not the RISC OS emulator.

Visit our new RISC OS Kickstarter that is still open for funding the next 12 days.

updates.update_content:
After we reached our financial goal of 6.000 Euro after 9 days we have reached 10.000 Euro yesterday.
We have decided to offer an additional reward for all Cloverleaf RISC  OS distribution pledgers, Kitten Pi Desktop PC, Puma Desktop PC and the  RK3399 RISC OS image for the PineBookPro if we reach 15.000 Euro.
We will add a free copy of !ArtCube photo editor to all this pledges.

updates.update_userinfo: Mesa 3D GPU driver for the RockChip RK3399
updates.update_content:
We are happy to announce that Simon Wilson has committed himself once again to RISC OS and wants to work with us to create a Mesa 3D GPU driver for the RockChip RK3399.
Simon obtained extensive experience with GPU drivers while working for Qualcomm to port Android GPU drivers for the Snapdragon SOCs. Simon is also an experienced RISC OS programmer who implemented the IyonixMesa, PCI TV and SoundBlaster drivers.
We also plan to create a library that makes the Mesa OpenGL API available to BBC BASIC.

updates.update_userinfo: Goal missed but going to make a re-launch.
updates.update_content:
Thank you for your support!

We've fallen a bit short of our goal, but we're determined to plow ahead and make RISC OS Cloverleaf a reality! As you should know you will not be charged your pledges when we don't reach the goal.

We've gotten tons of great questions, insights, and thoughts that we've used to improve our project. Thank you so much for being a backer. 

More than ever before, we think it's important to provide alternative choices from the main operating systems available. We want to revitalize and upgrade RISC OS for you. 

We're going to transition our Kickstarter campaign to Indiegogo and after that re-launch with a lower goal here at Kickstarter. 

You can expect our Indiegogo to go live in less 2 weeks. 

You will hear from me via email, a Kickstarter update, and our Facebook group (https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/riscos-cloverleaf/cloverleaf-built-on-the-powerful-open-source-risc-os).

I hope you choose to continue to participate, and if you have any questions, you can shoot me a direct message here or post in our group on Facebook. 

Thank you,

Stefan

RISC OS offers multiple emulators for older computer systems like the Sinclair ZX Spectrum, Acorn Micro, Acorn Archimedes, Commodore C64 and MS DOS. We have planned to include a number of retro games from various plattforms in our Cloverleaf RISC OS distribution. Recently we got hinted that this might cause legal issues as including these games is only allowed if no profit is made from it unless you get permission by the author or get a license. Therefore we have to change our plans and will offer a way to easily download these games from various sources.

campaign.story:
ShadowCast is the simplest way to play console games on your computer. TVs aren’t always convenient so we made a way to take console gaming with you wherever you are without the need of an internet connection.       



As lifelong console gamers, we know there may be some PC master race gamers who gawk at the idea of playing Mario on their powerful gaming computer.  But we say the more games we can play, on even more platforms, the better! 
Seamless console docking to your laptop. It's that simple!
Laptops are Really Versatile Screens
The biggest benefit of course is to take advantage of the screen you’re always carrying already.  Not one of those additional portable monitors but a laptop that we use daily for like… school, work, shopping and creative stuff. 
ShadowCast completely hides in the shadows of the original Switch dock!
Let's imagine a time before 2020... and you were waiting at an airport for a flight to board and you wanted to get a couple rounds of Smash Bros in with a friend… or two… or three. Tabletop mode is nice… but let’s just say it’s not the most ergonomic. With ShadowCast you can easily plug your Nintendo Switch to your laptop and play on a screen over 4x the size.
Not quite as easy as adjusting the viewing angle of a laptop, is it?
You Could Always use Another TV
There's also many situations where there just isn’t a HDMI display available - many of us are happy with our laptops and integrated desktop computers. I think back to the times when I lived in a dorm room or even living abroad for brief periods where having my laptop, a PS5, and a ShadowCast would’ve been amazing. 
Works with current-gen and next-gen with up to 4K input
And then there’s always competing for the living room television - whether it’s someone in your household streaming a whole season of the latest Netflix series or just having another gamer in the household. Oh and it also makes having a second television for multiplayer that much more convenient to set up. 
PS5 on an iMac - when a TV just simply isn't available
Our App Makes the Difference
Accompanying the ShadowCast is our new Genki Arcade app. We literally have made it easier than reaching for the TV remote and hitting the "input" button. We've designed Genki Arcade from the ground up to minimize computing resources and prioritize latency for gaming performance. Just open the app, and it'll auto detect ShadowCast and you'll be playing immediately without any settings to fiddle with.
TV vs. ShadowCast - HDMI splitter shows a 0-0.02s difference in Smash Bros.
Genki Arcade (left) is 50ms faster than OBS (right) and uses less than 1/3 of the CPU
We've developed a native Mac OS app that's optimized for both Apple Silicon and Intel processors as well as a dedicated app for Windows. Additionally, we're in the process of making a web browser version that allows you to play on shared/public computers and other systems without installing any software (compatibility will vary, for example iPadOS currently doesn’t detect external video devices but we’re confident it will someday!).
Windows or Mac, we got your Animal Crossing addiction covered
 The beauty of being able to connect your gaming console to your computer means you can actually record, edit, and stream your gameplay. While it may not be at the same level as a professional grade capture card that costs 5-10x more, it’s more than capable for most gameplay capturing needs while being much more flexible and easy to use across multiple platforms. 
We're making last year's best capture cards feel a bit outdated.
Record To Your Heart’s Content
Sure you can use the built-in video recording feature on the Nintendo Switch but that’s limited to 30 seconds - that mean you'll have to rush that epic boss fight or finish that speed-run extra fast.  It's is also a pain to export and you’re limited by an already small internal storage and expensive memory cards. With ShadowCast you don't have to worry about recording length and can rewatch your whole session of Among Us, add your commentary, and refine your strategy.
With a 30 second limit everyone is sus!
We’ve actually created what we believe is the most simple to use, not just for playing but also to record gameplay videos.  Here’s a sample of a recording of us playing on various consoles with the ShadowCast: 
These videos are screen recordings of gameplay played off an early build of our dedicated Genki Arcade app.
Plays Nice with Others 
We made the Genki Arcade app to be truly simple to use, but for those that need more complexity you’ll be happy to know that ShadowCast is compatible with popular professional capture card applications such as Open Broadcaster Software (OBS), Streamlabs OBS, XSplit, and much more. This will allow you to capture video with detailed customizations and even overlay various webcam feeds, graphics, and animations.
It's pretty much compatible with everything you throw at it

Begin Your Career as an Influencer
Ultimately the main reason for anyone to capture video is so that they can share it with the world. ShadowCast can easily upload your previously recorded or edited videos and even stream live to your favorite platform - whether your team Twitch, YouTube, or FaceBook, we got you covered.  
To maximize compatibility across as many platforms as possible, we’ve disguised ShadowCast as a webcam so that it can do a few more party tricks. This means it can actually be selected as a webcam under many typical apps popular today thanks to all the remote working, including Zoom, Google Meet, Microsoft Teams, and FaceTime - and further even supports video players like QuickTime and VLC if you don’t have our app installed.
Video Chat Your Gameplay
This allows you to not only share your gameplay live with anyone, but you can actually play with your friends and see them on split screen just as if you were playing in couch co-op mode in-person.
You can play any of your favorite games in split-screen even without being on a couch
Don’t Settle for a Weak Webcam
As an additional benefit, ShadowCast works with all HDMI output devices beyond gaming consoles, including better cameras.  This means you can upgrade your video conference by swapping out your poor built-in webcam for most digital cameras, including DSLRs, camcorders, and action cameras - as long as it supports HDMI out (some cameras require a HDMI-mini/micro converter).  No more grainy, low resolution videos with poor lighting. 
Kickstarter compresses these images, but hopefully you get the idea!
The Perfect Stay-at-Home Camera Assistant
It’s also quite useful for situations where you just need to see what you're photographing or recording on a bigger laptop screen - no need for expensive wireless monitors! 
A better view of your DSLR in real-time so you can skip the expensive screen monitor
We actually had the idea of ShadowCast back in 2019 and started to collaborate with  manufacturers of the top video streaming and capture card brands. The timing was a bit too early as the components needed were overly expensive and had originally intended to make a Super Dock. Since then, we've refined the idea, dived into software and made something that we're quite excited to share here.
Might as well make it as small as possible right?
Here's also a video showcasing the latency between a TV and ShadowCast. We setup a powered HDMI splitter to show the screens simultaneously with the same baseline:
PLAY

Setup ShadowCast in 3 simple steps!
If you need a more visual adventure we've prepared a short video showing the 3 simple steps in real-time to setup ShadowCast.
PLAY

This is really, really small
Dimensions are 25 x 52 x 9mm or 0.98" x 2.1" x 0.35"
Weighs just 10 grams (latest prototype)
HDMI 2.0 input brings in 4K video from the latest game consoles, including the Nintendo Switch, Playstation 4/5, and XBox Series S/X
USB-C output transfers to computer up to 1920x1080 @ 60fps
Genki Arcade app requires macOS 10.12+ or Windows 7+
Includes USB-C 2.0 Cable 1.8m long cable


 Get more ShadowCasts if you wanted various colors or one for every console:
Get a Covert Dock, a pocketable dock and GaN charger for the Switch and more:
Get a Genki Audio, connects 2 Bluetooth headphones to your Switch (and other consoles) works docked, and has a port to charge your Switch:
Get a Genki Audio Lite, a slimmer portable Bluetooth audio adapter that is optimized for the Switch and Switch Lite (does not fit PS5): 
Get a Force Field Lite, a dual magnetic enclosure grip case with vegan leather to protect your Switch Lite with compatibility for both Genki Audio and Audio Lite:

Genki was a brand founded by three guys with a dream to challenge the gaming accessory industry to make more compelling hardware.  Eddie, Chris, and Andrew miss the good old days of gaming accessories that truly improved the console experience such as the Game Genie, GameBoy Light Magnifier, and Guncon.  But we didn't do this alone, and there's a lot of people to thank for bringing this project to life:
 Alex Miller for developing our fantastically optimized Genki Arcade app

And of course, we want to thank backers like you. With your crowdfunding support we’ve been able to operate as a quirky indie hardware developer free from outside investors. This means we can keep our focus on designing innovative human things we believe in without compromises.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We launched the most funded gaming hardware project on Kickstarter of 2018 and 2019 so we've been through this rodeo. By now the risks are less of us being able to make the product but more likely if we deliver on time. One of the biggest chunks of time is always the pre-production phase which includes tooling/mold production, test molds, and securing components. This time, we’ve actually gotten a lot of the work done before launching the project which means greater financial risk for us but a lot less timeline uncertainty for our backers. We're happy to say we're even better equipped to face these challenges but no matter how much we plan there’s always a chance that things can go wrong. Whether its production, logistics, or completely random events, we promise to always share with you full transparency on our hiccups and resolve them in a way that keeps our backers happy and proud to keep supporting Genki.

Note: there are some shipping risks now to certain countries dealing with uncertainty such as the UK (Brexit) and new India import tariffs. Regional lockdowns also impact postal services but we'll do our best to get ShadowCast to you wherever you are.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Long-lasting design
Our product physically uses the least material resources through a minimized design - nearly 10x smaller and less build material than similar consumer hardware. It's designed to last across console generations for as long as HDMI is the standard.

The First Shipment
So the good news is we are done with production of the Early Access batch and will be distributing to global warehouses so that we can get packages to you in a quick and reliable manner. While we have 30,000 backers, what's even crazier is that we'll be shipping to 96 countries. This is definitely a record for us, and luckily we're tackling this in monthly batches this time. campaign.story:
COSMIC FRONTIER: OVERRIDE
“Cosmic Frontiers are calling!”
Concept art by Chris Smallfield
Explore the galaxy. Fight aliens; befriend aliens. Make a fortune through trade — or through piracy! Chart your own course among the stars, or find yourself at the heart of dramatic events: turn the tide of wars, develop new technologies, and destabilise entire cultures!
Cosmic Frontier: Override is a single-player space-trading game in the mold of the inspirational Elite (1984). It is a remake of Escape Velocity: Override (1998), by the same scenario designer. It is planned to be released for Mac, Windows PC and Linux systems, with a target release date in the middle of 2021. We are seeking your backing to meet that target and release a game of the highest quality possible!
Planet landing concept art by Chris Smallfield
GAMEPLAY
As in Elite and other games like it, the core gameplay involves piloting your ship from one star system to another, visiting planets and space stations, buying and selling goods to make a profit, while evading or fighting pirates and other threats. When you make enough money, you can upgrade your ship with new equipment and weapons, or buy an entirely new ship which may have drastically different capabilities.
The main difference between Cosmic Frontier and Elite is that it features a top-down view, like that of Asteroids, rather than being a flight sim. The result is an easy-to-learn game with a great atmosphere of adventure, suitable for both quick bites of play or long gaming sessions. We’re certain that any fan of the Escape Velocity games will enjoy Cosmic Frontier, but the game is intended to be easy for the most casual pilot to pick up and play.
Cosmic Frontier is a free-form game: you can go wherever you want, and work for whomever you want — including for no one but yourself. You can be a peaceful trader, a bounty hunter, a soldier for Earth, a galactic explorer, a rapacious pirate — or all of these and more in the life of a single pilot! In addition, there are dozens of story-line missions which advance events within the game universe and provide unique challenges and opportunities. But it is also quite possible to avoid all this scripted content and still experience many hours of rich gameplay.
To get a fuller idea of the gameplay, or to summon up some nostalgia if you played the original game many years ago, please take a look at ASW Fangirl's youtube playthrough.
SCENARIO
It is 150 years into the future. Humanity has achieved interstellar travel, but soon after doing so it became embroiled in a war with the pitiless Voinians, imperialistic aliens who see humans as just one more inferior species to enslave or annihilate.
The Voinians were halted at the Battle of Sol, but the conflict remains in the balance and battles continue to rage on the frontier just a few hyperjumps from Earth. Nearly all of humankind’s energies are poured into this struggle for survival, and little of the rest of the accessible galaxy has been explored.
You begin as a solo pilot, with nothing but a shuttlecraft, a hyperflight licence and a handful of credits to your name, determined to make your fortune among the stars.
To players of the original Escape Velocity: Override, all of the above will sound familiar. They can be assured that all the best things from the original game will be preserved, and that there will be expanded content including new ship types and new mission strings. In addition, there will be a prequel mini-scenario, covering the period of humanity’s first encounter with the Voinians, which will be released as DLC free to backers at the $10 level and above.
Cosmic Frontier: Override will feature:
Hundreds of star systems, planets and space stations to visit
Dozens of different classes of ship to pilot, and fight against
Numerous human and alien factions with their own characteristic technologies
A wide range of weapons and equipment for your ship
Hundreds of missions, including some which will change the face of the galaxy
Please note that, unless otherwise indicated, all screenshots come from the original game, Escape Velocity: Override, and are not representative of the final product
MODDABILITY
Among the most important features of Cosmic Frontier will be moddability: Escape Velocity was a pioneering game in terms of the ease of content modification and creation by users, and both its sequels derived from content initially created by mod developers.
Cosmic Frontier too will be highly moddable. Shortly after the game’s release, a free mod developer’s kit will be released that will include a full guide to the scripting language that any user will be able to use to make their own additions or modifications to the scenario, or to create entirely new scenarios of their own. This includes the creation of new ships, new weapons, new outfits, new missions, new star systems and visitable worlds and stations, and a host of other features.
The new engine will have extensive compatibility with the resource files used by the Escape Velocity games. At worst, it will only take a small amount of conversion effort to get your old EV mods working with Cosmic Frontier. At best, it may prove possible to just plug them in and play!
Moddability is very important to us. Many people got their first taste of software development and graphic design through working on Escape Velocity projects, and we hope that the same will be true for Cosmic Frontier in the future. In addition, if this project is successfully funded, we hope that Override will not be the only Cosmic Frontier game we release … 
ENGINE
Cosmic Frontier will feature a brand new game engine which will at least match the capabilities of the game engines of the games in the Escape Velocity series. In the future, we intend for this engine to be available for use by further projects, both by us and independently of us. Helping to fund Cosmic Frontier will also help to fund development of this game engine.
The engine itself is referred to by the name Kestrel. For practical reasons, Kestrel will not be source-available during the initial run of development, but following the release of Cosmic Frontier: Override it will become open-source, with a licence that will allow people to use it as the main engine in the development of their own games.
Kestrel will permit modification of the game on four different levels:
1. Base Engine (C++). For fundamental changes, such as graphics rendering and physics calculations.
2. Core Gameplay (Lua) - Changing how the resources and assets of the game are handled and the game experience is delivered.
3. Mods (Lua) - Additional functionality, and changes to core functionality.
4. Plugins - Traditional EV-style plugins that add content to the game without altering functionality.
You can read more and follow future progress on the Kestrel development blog. 
An example of the Kestrel Development Language
FUNDING GOALS
Our initial funding target of $45 000 is set based on the amount of part-time and spare-time work we expect to put in to bring you the game by the middle of 2021. (Please keep in mind that we do not get every cent of the funding: there are fees to Kickstarter, payment processing fees, and also taxes to take into account.) A healthy funding amount will help us enormously in justifying to our families the amount of time and energy we have already put into this project. The greater the funding, the more time and effort we will be able to put in.
In addition, neither of the developers are primarily artists. Funding will enable us to commission artists, or even add an artist to the team if we meet the first stretch goal below, which will allow us to add new and improve existing art assets, and ensure a smooth, polished user interface.
We believe that the main funding target will be sufficient for us to at least match the quality of experience of the original Escape Velocity games, re-scaled and adjusted for modern displays and other gaming norms. In addition, there will be new scenario content including new ships and missions.
Stretch Goal 1 — Graphical Upgrade — $60 000
Should we reach the $60 000 level, we will commit to a full graphical upgrade and overhaul of the original, which we will most likely look to achieve by adding a third member to the development team, who will focus on graphic design.
Part of the charm of the Escape Velocity games was always that any would-be modder felt that they could be capable of creating content that didn’t look out of place alongside the original work, and therefore we don’t want to set the graphical bar so high that the same won’t be true of Cosmic Frontier. So the focus will be on crisp, clear design and UI, putting new polish on existing Override assets and creating new content that fits in seamlessly.
We don’t have any definite candidate in mind for this role at this time, but would be looking for someone with both a background in playing and modding the EV games, and some experience of professional graphic design.
Short of this milestone, we will focus on producing and commissioning specific pieces of art in order to smooth out the original Override look as far as is feasible.
Stretch Goal 2 — Age of the Council — $100 000
At the $100 000 level, we will have the confidence to guarantee the release of a sequel to the Override scenario, entitled Age of the Council. This will be planned for release between 12 and 18 months after the initial release of Cosmic Frontier as paid-for DLC.
The bones of the Age of the Council scenario already exist, including the design of many new ships and weapons. The scenario takes place in essentially the same map of systems as Override, but begins 25 years later and (in addition to the impact of the pilot’s actions in Override) there have been many other changes to the political shape of the galaxy — and there will be still more in the course of the plot!
Draft ship designs for Age of the Council
And beyond: We don’t have any further specific stretch goals beyond these at this time, but the greater the funding level, the more ambitious we will be able to be in terms of: (1) bringing you the highest quality remaster of Override possible; (2) creating more content in the Override universe; (3) building the most complete and flexible game engine possible; and (4) planning for future games under the Cosmic Frontier title in new original settings.
Important reward tier note: If you are generous enough to fund us at a level where you get the chance to add new missions, a new ship type or other features to the game, we will do our best to implement your vision. However, we may have to impose certain limitations or guidelines to ensure that your addition fits in seamlessly with the rest of the design.

WHO WE ARE
Tom Hancocks — Engine Developer
Tom is a software engineer who has worked with Apple's Cocoa frameworks for the past 16 years, and had some experience with Carbon and REALbasic before that. His first commercial project was a utility called TuneBar, which acted as a controller for iTunes, allowing users to control iTunes from within any other application on their system. The Escape Velocity series played a large part in expanding his interest in software development, and has been a game that he has periodically returned to. When he noticed that macOS Yosemite was beginning to emit warnings of incompatibility over EV Nova, he began to look into cloning the engine and reverse-engineering the old file and media formats that it had used.
Peter Cartwright — Scenario Designer
Peter began creating the scenario for Escape Velocity: Override shortly after the release of the original Escape Velocity, and Ambrosia Software picked it up as that game’s first sequel shortly after he had left school. Although he has continued to do some game modding — including being a small part of the Magna Mundi team for Europa Universalis III — he did not stay in software development, mainly working as a freelance international translator, including for organisations such as the United Nations.
Both members of the team happen to be from the east of England.
Override Theme Music by Nolan Markey.
"Cosmic Frontiers are calling!" and "Greetings from the Cosmic Frontier" poster images by Chris Smallfield.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This will be the first independent software project for both of us. Between us, we have considerable experience in software design, modding, project management, and independent, freelance work and are confident in our ability to take on this challenge. The foundation of the scenario content already exists and the goals for game engine development are clearly defined.

However, life is unpredictable and we are just two people, not an extensive studio team. We can’t rule out the possibility that unexpected events may delay or derail the project.

That said, if you entrust us with your money we will take that responsibility seriously, and provide you with monthly updates in order to assure you that development is on track.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi backers!

One major piece of news this month, and we hope it won't prove too much of a disappointment for you.

Tom and I have put our heads together and concluded that we won't be able to achieve the estimated release date of July 2021. We haven't nailed down a new planned release date exactly, but we now aim to release the game before the end of 2021.
The last couple of months of development has been interesting. I have a few things that I want to share this time, and they relate to Windows, Metal and AI.

Hi backers!
Apologies for the delayed update again. Truth is, my regular job (translation) involves looking at screens, so does Cosmic Frontier work, of course, and England is... well, to be honest, I've lost track of whether we're in lock-down or not, but things are certainly still a mess and there's no sense in going out too much without reason whatever the case. So that's meant a lot of time indoors which tends to end up with... staring at screens. Suffice to say, I've been waking up with bad cases of eye strain so I've had to take it easy and take a break from screens as much as possible.

The last couple of months have been intense, to say the least. Not only have we had Christmas, but my family and I have moved house (right before Christmas for those extra stress points). Despite everything happening, I have still been putting as much into Cosmic Frontier as possible.

Happy New Year, backers!

First of all, I'd like to apologise for the delay in this update. I haven't been very well since the turn of the year (don't worry — nothing topical), and just as I was starting to get this written earlier this week I ended up getting completely distracted following the news of the recent events in Washington.

Hi backers!
Nothing earth-shaking to report to you this month. At least on my part, it feels like we're in the deep, dark woods of the process, caught up in all kinds of small but necessary details while feeling a long way from anything recognisable as an end product. I hope that things should begin to come together in the new year.
Tom has been continuing to work on the new engine and its interaction with Nova-era data files, although this has been disrupted by the process of moving house -- a challenging operation at the best of times as I'm sure you'll realise.

Last month I gave you an update about Kestrel. This month I’m giving an update regarding Cosmic Frontier itself. This months post will be relatively brief as both myself and Peter have once again turned out to be quite busy.
Current Progress
Right now I’m working to make the foundation Cosmic Frontier. This will be a game engine that has feature parity to the Nova engine. It will be backwards compatible with Nova era plugins and content. The plan is that I will then introduce the new functionality for Cosmic Frontier on top of this.

After the events of August, which led to most of the month being pretty much a write off for both of us, September has decided to allow a lot more to happen. This update will contain a bit of technical information, as the subject of this update will be the Kestrel Game Engine.
Let’s kick things off by saying that the initial pre-alpha version of Kestrel has been published! You can check out the project repository on GitHub: https://github.com/EvocationGames/KestrelEngine

campaign.story:
Hacker-Themed Apparel to Support Free Software!
Our organization works hard every day to make the Internet safer for all of us. We are constantly fighting for more donations and we are getting a state-of-the art Direct-to-Garment printer to help our cause. 
This KickStarter is a wonderful opportunity for us to create some hacker-themed swag for our supporters and become a revenue source for us to use over the long-term. By fronting all of the orders for garments on Kickstarter, we eliminate the risk in having to finance the equipment. With the equipment fully paid for, we will add a crucial revenue stream to our project so that we can get more of our crucial work funded.
The Plan
OSTIF is kicking-in half of the funding for the new equipment from our own donated funds from previous projects, and we are raising the other half through this KickStarter. We have carefully selected commercial-grade equipment, high quality materials, and gathered volunteers to work on the production of the shirts and wallets. 
We have commissioned multiple designs and our staff has created multiple others, and the designs are all shirts we would wear ourselves. Many of these designs are appearing on this KickStarter for the first time and can't be found anywhere else!
All of the designs shown below are available in a "Men's" Tee, a "Women's" Tee, and a Unisex Fleece hoodie.
We discuss the designs of the rewards below:
The Designs
These are RFID-blocking wallets that block "drive-by" readers from scanning cards in your pocket. You can custom engrave them with whatever you want (Obviously nothing copyrighted or illegal, and it must be two-tone black and white. The maximum print area is about the size of the pictures shown in the KS gallery.) 
This design is a space-twist on the Tux the Linux Penguin. It is very high resolution and looks fantastic!
The two designs above are a new design based on the old Jolly Roger flag. It features a skull and cross-keys design. The black shirt design has a bright glowing effect with a blue hue and the white shirt has a more subdued two-tone "posterized" design. 
 Update: This design was just added! It commemorates our collaborative work with the Monero and Arweave projects to do an intense audit of RandomX, a new proof of work algorithm that multiple cryptocurrency projects have now adopted. It features a block of encrypted text that is garbled and unreadable, with a large X-shaped area of the text block glowing in "Monero orange" with clearer encrypted text. It is a high resolution design that doesn't show well in mockups, because we can't cram enough pixles into the maximum file size to show the details.
 This retro design represents OSTIF.org's anti-censorship work on the obfs4, shadowsocks, meeklite, and meekheavy projects. These technologies help break censorship in authoritarian regimes around the world. We are working to make them more secure, easier to use, and more effective.
This design shows Edward Snowden in a mosaic built out of computer text (ASCII). Snowden revealed worldwide illegal surveillance programs being conducted by the National Security Agency (NSA) and the Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ).
This design is made to look like a band world tour shirt, but it is showing the real locations of large organizations that were struck by the leaked EternalBlue vulnerability. EternalBlue was a vulnerability that was originally found by the NSA, and instead of reporting the issue to Microsoft for a fix, they left systems worldwide vulnerable and built tools to exploit it. These tools leaked and ultimately became the WannaCry and NotPetya ransomwares that did billions of dollars in damage from downtime and destroyed data.
 This design is titled "The Internet is Beautiful and Dangerous." The jellyfish design has Ethernet cables for tentacles and the bell has the international symbol for WiFi.
 This design is not just a stylized version of our org's name. We have hidden the Glider symbol in the design. The Glider is a symbol of hacker culture and it represents a simple shape that glides when it is used in the "Game of Life" originally designed by John Conway in the 1970's. The game has incredibly deep complexity while having deceptively simple starting conditions. An example of the game is here: https://playgameoflife.com/
 These bright designs represent the growth of the open source community with circuit-board traces and icons representing the many uses of open source software.

This design is a front and back design that features our organization name on the front, and on the back, it shows an actual NSA document leaked by Edward Snowden that shows that the US National Security Agency cannot decrypt an Off-The-Record encrypted message. It shows that even with the NSA's vast resources and manpower, properly built encryption systems prevail.
 This design represents the security audit work that we do, with a magnifying glass revealing "horrors" inside of your devices. It is meant to represent possible back doors in proprietary systems, such as the Intel Management Engine, AMD Platform Security Processor, or the ARM TrustZone, as well as all of the problems with Spectre, ZombieLoad, RIDL, and other security flaws that organizations try to fix with updates.
This design satirically calls out the biggest three "surveillance as a business" companies in the world with the warning "BIOHAZARD - AVOID CONTACT WITH EYES." One design features just the biohazard symbol with the companies, and an alternative design includes a faint skull in the background, with two of the glowing company logos over the eye sockets.
Here are two Monero designs. Being the largest privacy-oriented cryptocurrency in the world, we have worked closely with the Monero project on key features that have shrank transaction sizes, sped up the network, and hardened the blockchain against the rise of application specific integrated circuits (ASICs). We have worked together on Monero BulletProofs, and Monero RandomX and we currently working closely on two other projects now.
This next design is a play on the "OK Boomer" designs that are floating around the web. It is the same style of lettering, but says "OK Facebook" using fake Cyrillic text. Instead of the "have a terrible day", it has a defeatist mantra of "overthrow my government." This is to point out the unchecked Russian (and other) influence campaigns on Facebook and their failure to rein in international campaigns to undermine governments and reshape people's opinions.
This design symbolizes the growth of the Open Source Movement and its rise to wide adoption, with our role in improving project code quality and security. It features the word "FIGHT" with the "i" being symbolized by a tree made up of circuit-board traces.
The next one should be appreciated by programmers and security engineers alike! This is our "typewriter" design, featuring a typewriter that shows an actual critical flaw that was found by OSTIF while reviewing OpenVPN 2.4.0.
This is a two-sided design titled "resist surveillance." It features a symbol of resistance over the United State's NSA logo.
The Windows Elephant design has a double meaning, one is superficial and the other is much deeper. Generally Windows is considered bloated and slow when compared to competing Linux solutions for a lot of tasks, hence the elephant failing to jump the chasm. The deeper meaning surrounds the removal of the Elephant Diffuser from BitLocker drive encryption. Removing this key component was against the advice of Microsoft's own cryptographers because it significantly weakens Bitlocker. Micah Lee wrote an excellent article explaining the situation here: https://theintercept.com/2015/06/04/microsoft-disk-encryption/ In essence, Microsoft weakened their encryption for Windows on purpose by killing the Elephant Diffuser.
This design is a tongue in cheek joke meme started in the early 2000's when Steve Ballmer of Microsoft famously said that "Linux is a cancer that attaches itself in an intellectual property sense to everything it touches." He then went on to compare Linux and the Free Software movement to communism. Today, Linux is a dominating presence on servers, in the cloud, and on smartphones everywhere.

Update: This design was just added! It's a Monero Chameleon. It symbolizes Monero's focus on privacy and fungibility.
Update: This design was just added! It's a play on words for "fungible" a key feature that Monero focuses on.
Below are our additional designs from our backers and staff. If you have a design idea that you'd like to share with us to use on this fundraiser, you can reach us at donate@ostif.org.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Our risks for the project are limited. We have done our research into shipping costs, customs issues, material costs, labor and reasonable fault rates (misprinted shirts, etc). A faulty printer could delay shipping but would not ultimately interfere with product being delivered. A cushion has been worked into the budget to accommodate any issues with unexpectedly high shipping or material shipping costs to ensure that the project has everything it needs to succeed. Any overages raised by this fundraiser will go directly to the cause (our next major security project).
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.title: Proto-HyperCube (10")
support.descp:
Can't wait to get your HyperCube? Receive one of our initial 10" prototype cubes as soon as it's ready (likely around February, but no promises), in addition to a 10" cube of the final design in August 2019. We will name your proto-cube something unique and luminous (Apollo, Helios, etc - or of your own choosing), to be engraved on a plaque on the frame, along with it's production number.
The prototype will be our initial run of cubes and be very similar to the final version, but may have slight design differences that we're looking to improve upon. Either way, the prototype will be fully functional.
AND this tier includes a 30 minute Skype call with us, to discuss our project, life, the universe, and anything else you may fancy!
Shipping is not included for either cube received at this tier.

campaign.story:
The Nutshell
Learn Scala by having fun. Learn advanced Scala. Learn really well by coding a huge amount. Write more code during play than you do at work or at school.
The Game
ScalaQuest takes place in DataLand, a place where land produces data, and its inhabitants harvest data to survive.
In DataLand, many mysterious forces have arisen, with mystical names such as 4-train, C-cross-cross and Hava. They all made data harvesting more efficient, but they all came with dangers of their own. Eventually, Complexity Plagues appeared, forces became slow and inefficient. Whole crops were lost. Those were difficult times for all.
Within DataLand, a powerful wizard named Ski has roamed for a while, taming many of these forces. Recently, he's discovered a new force and named it Scala.
However, Ski knows this great power needs to be wielded wisely, so he's gathering an order of apprentices, who can use Scala skillfully and with great care.
He's called this the Order of The Ski, or Order[Ski] for short.
This is where you come in. 
You shall become his apprentice, and learn Scala through practice and peril. You will start on the warm, safe haven of Values and Expressions, cross the Classes and Objects plains, hike over Variance Hills and make your way to the treacherous Implicit Forests.
And after that? Who knows what lies ahead.
Warning: This might be the first time you ask your team members to play a game during work hours.
Why Scala?
Scala is a programming language that mixes Object Oriented and Functional Programming. It has been adopted by organizations such as Twitter, LinkedIn, Netflix and Duolingo, and it has enjoyed steady growth for several years. Lately, investment in the language has come from companies like Intel, IBM and Juniper Networks. Its developer community is sharp, curious and dynamic.
Scala is being used in solid frameworks like Akka, Spark and Play, and is gaining much traction in Data Analysis, Machine Learning and Reactive Systems.
If you're a developer, having Scala under your belt can open up exciting job opportunities.
The content
Our goal is to cover a range of topics well beyond the very basics, including:
Values and expressions 
Classes and Types
Objects 
Case Classes
Value Classes
Functions
Inheritance
Options
Pattern Matching
Collections
Error Handling 
Implicits
Currying
Variance and Covariance
The type system
MONADS. Yes, Mondays. I mean Monads.
Each level will typically focus on one topic, but as you advance you will be prompted to reinforce your existing knowledge.
Who we are
As a Senior Software Developer & Trainer, Alejandro splits his time between architecting and building software, and coaching others on how to effectively use the Lightbend Reactive Platform. He has a strong passion for teaching, and is one of the few certified Lightbend trainers in Scala, Akka and Play. Over the last 4 years, he has taught over a thousand people from a variety of companies, ranging from startups like Hootsuite and large corporations like Intel and IBM. Alejandro has also created strong connections with many experts involved in building and supporting these platforms. (More about Alejandro)
Christian is an experienced software developer who has been around a few blocks, and is still trying to find the safest neighbourhood to hang out in. Professionally he is somewhat of a generalist. His love for Scala started a few years ago when he was exposed to its capacity for brevity, its hiding of redundancy found in other languages, all the while being unwary of the dangerous hidden parts. Now he believes the way forward is to come to terms with acceptance - that no advanced language can ever be fully understood, yet sufficient patience and effort can still lead to skill, power and accomplishment. (More about Christian)
Why do you care?
You will want to back up this project if:
You want to learn Scala from scratch and have no time for nonsense
You want to level up your Scala skillz
You want to grow your Scala team
You want to encourage others to learn the language
You think great learning should be super affordable
How will you learn Scala?
We strongly believe fun is a multiplying factor for learning.
When you're having fun, you're more engaged and tend to retain more information.
Play is the highest form of research. -- Albert Einstein
Surely, Einstein was referring to the Zelda series here!
The best moments usually occur when a person’s body or mind is stretched [...] in a voluntary effort to accomplish something difficult and worthwhile. -- Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, Flow (1990)
If you're working at a task that's too easy, you get bored. Too hard, and you ragequit.
As developers, we also call this Flow, and we crave it often - but do we leverage 'fun' and 'games' enough for learning?
Learning Scala is difficult and worthwhile... but can we make it **fun**?
Repetition. In order to survive the quest, you will need to write a lot of code. Exercises will rarely repeat, but we will ensure that every concept is covered from as many angles as possible. You will write lots of code.
Observation. As developers, we spend more time reading code than writing. We'll challenge you to read, understand and fix Scala snippets.
Metaphors. We believe the right metaphors can unblock learners from understanding hard concepts. The further the metaphor from code and software, the better. We will use the game environment to create these metaphors and help you develop an intuition for hard concepts.
That is our goal with ScalaQuest.
What about other learning options?
Yes, there are great training courses out there, some in pure digital form, others delivered by human beings.
But not everyone learns the same way. 
We believe there's space for many different learning environments, and we've challenged ourselves to build one we really like!
In addition, we're creating a very affordable platform, that would allow you to learn at a monthly price that you can simply forget about.
Where the project is at
We've made tremendous progress and already have two working levels, with number 3 coming very soon. We plan on having beta testers in the near future to validate and improve our current direction. As a backer, you will be invited to participate in this phase, of course!
For some of the heavy lifting (compiling and running user code) we'll be integrating with Scastie in the near future.
Our goals
Our goal with ScalaQuest is to provide a relatively humane path to learning the basics and the intermediate parts of the deep world of Scala. We want learners to experience success and failure in the form of adventure, laughter and death, rather than in the form of confusion and self-doubt. ScalaQuest is a safe place to play with fire!
Our objective is to launch ScalaQuest with 8 complete levels, which we believe will take us the rest of 2017. Our goal then is to have a publicly available game by January 2018.
After launching the game, our goal is to release one new level per month. As a player, you'll want to keep coming back for more content.
How else can I get involved?
You can follow us on Twitter and share our news with your friends.
